author: Merryn Porter
title: Triplets: Ultrasound changed the life of mum-to-be who supports The Royal Giving Day | Exclusive - 9Honey
text:
Myfanwy Schostakowski was about six weeks pregnant when she went to her first pregnancy ultrasound at the end of 2022.
Schostakowski, of Sydney's Eastern Suburbs, and her husband Benjamin had been trying for about two years to add to their family following the birth of son George in 2017.
When tests confirmed she was pregnant, Schostakowski decided to have an ultrasound two weeks later after becoming convinced she was having twins, despite there being no family history of multiple births .
But as the sonographer waved the wand over her stomach, Schostakowski realised something was amiss.
READ MORE: 'Best friend's dad's name': The new baby name trend set to take off in 2025
Myfanwy Schostakowski with her triplets soon after their birth. (Supplied) "We were with the sonographer and she said, 'Is this natural or IVF?' and 'Do you have any other children?'" Schostakowski recalled.
"Then she starts wiping all the gel off [my stomach] after only a couple of minutes and said, 'I am going to leave the room and grab my colleague.'"
Fearing the worst, ï»¿Schostakowski begged the sonographer for more information.
"I said, 'If there is no heartbeat, you have to tell me,' and she said 'No, there are three heartbeats, I think it's triplets.'
"Then I just remember my husband nearly fainted and said 'Triplets!' in this high-pitched voice."
READ MORE: Queen Elizabeth's final diary entry revealed
The ultrasound that showed Schostakowski was having triplets (Supplied) Schostakowski, who suffered from gestational diabetes during her previous pregnancy, said her mind raced with fears about her health and that of her unborn babies in the moments that followed.
Within hours of the ultrasound, she received a call from The Department of Maternal-Foetal Medicine (MFM) at the Royal Hospital for Women in Randwick.
The unit provides integrated multidisciplinary care to women experiencing a high-risk pregnancy.
"They rang and said, 'We know you found out today you are pregnant with triplets. How are you?'ï»¿" Schostakowski said.
"I found out on a Friday and they just said, 'You need to take the weekend to process it and we will talk to you again on Monday.'"
READ MORE: The one place Prince William says he can 'be himself'
The Sydney mum with husband Benjamin and son George shortly before she gave birth to triplets. (Supplied) By early in the new year, they had mapped out a plan to proceed with the pregnancy, which was deemed high-risk.
Nï»¿atural spontaneous triplets occur one in every 10,000 pregnancies. About half will be born before 32 weeks, and require treatment in a Neonatal or Newborn Intensive Care Unit (NICU).
"All the scenarios were explained. It was all very transparent about the risks," Schostakowski said.
The pregnancy was closely monitored, with monthly, then fortnightly and finally weekly appointments, with scans sometimes taking 3Â½ hours.
"Everything was explained at every part of their development. How they were measuring, their weight," she said.
"It was very stressful. Mental health is such a big part of any pregnancy but with a high-order multiple birth, more so." ï»¿
Schostakowski weighed more than 100kg and her skin would itch and burn. (Supplied) Schostakowski's health was also closely monitored. Her gestational diabetes was eventually managed with insulin, as her weight ballooned by more than 30 kilograms.
"We were never aiming to get to 40 weeks. We were hoping to get to 30 weeks and the maximum was 35 weeks," she said.
As the weeks went by, and the delivery date drew closer, social workers warned Schostakowski about what to expect.
Nurses also buoyed her spirits when she felt like she couldn't go on.
Finally, when ï»¿Schostakowski was approaching 33 weeks, a decision was made to admit her to hospital to administer the steroids needed to strengthen the babies' lungs ahead of their delivery, which was planned for later that week.
The triplets soon after their birth in the Royal Hospital for Women, Randwick. (Supplied) When the day finally arrived, Schostakowski walked herself to the elevator and then the operating suite where an elective caesarean was scheduled to take place.
Inside, she found a team of about 30 people waiting to deliver and care for the triplets.
She was able to stay calm by "thinking about all the team around me."
The top 10 names for boys and girls in the US revealed View Gallery The couple elected not to learn the sex of the babies, who were born within two minutes of each other on June 15, 2023, at 33 weeks and two days' gestation.
First was Ophelia, then Violet, and finally Ivy. While the two eldest suffered respiratory distress and were immediately whisked away, Ivy, the smallest of the trio, was able to have a quick cuddle in her mother's arms.
Hours laterï»¿, Schostakowski was reunited with her daughters in the hospital's NICU, where they spent two days before being moved to the special care nursery.
Myfanwy Schostakowski with her triplets. (Supplied) They went home, on the same day, five weeks later.
Schostakowski is speaking about the care she and her daughters received to support The Royal Giving Day on Wednesday, November 13, to raise much-needed funds for The Royal Hospital for Women.
As the only dedicated women's hospital in NSW, it plays a critical role in the health and well-being of women and newborn babies, but relies heavily on community support to fund state-of-the-art equipment, research and programs.
In fact, 80 per cent of the specialised medical equipment in the hospital's Newborn Intensive Care Unit was funded by donations.
The triplets are now 16 months old. (Supplied) These include the lifesaving humidicribs and CPAP machines used by the triplets.
"My girls needed that and if they didn't have access to that, they wouldn't be the healthy children they are now," Schostakowski said.
The 12-hour telethon style event is organised by the Royal Hospital for Women Foundation and has raised more than $750,000 since it was first held in 2021.
This year is extra special as it marks the hospital's 30th anniversary.ï»¿ All donations made by the public on the day will be matched by corporate donors.
Nine's Alex Cullen will host the event, which will be attended by former Aussie tennis player Casey Dellacqua, past and present Matildas players Nicola Bolger, Leigh Wardell and Julie Murray, Sydney Swans chief executive Tom Harley and his wife Felicity, Sydney Swans players and former hurdler Jana Pittman, who is now a doctor at the hospital.
"If they didn't have access to [the NICU's specialised equipment], they wouldn't be the healthy children they are now." (Supplied) Foundation chief executive Elise Jennings said funds raised on day support the hospital's work.
"All donations â€“ big or small â€“ make a real difference to the lives of the women and newborns we care for here at the Royal," she said.
More than 4000 babies were born at the hospital in the past year, while 10,000 women used the hospital's services, which include everything from maternity to oncology.
You can support the hospital here .ï»¿

author: Lucas Marques
title: ESPN Brasil afasta seis jornalistas apÃ³s debate sobre denÃºncias da CBF
text:
A ESPN Brasil afastou seis jornalistas apÃ³s a exibiÃ§Ã£o de um programa especial sobre a atuaÃ§Ã£o da ConfederaÃ§Ã£o Brasileira de Futebol (CBF), presidida por Ednaldo Rodrigues. A decisÃ£o ocorreu apÃ³s o grupo discutir as denÃºncias feitas pela revista PiauÃ­ sobre o comportamento do presidente da CBF. O debate aconteceu no programa Linha de Passe , transmitido na segunda-feira (7).
A informaÃ§Ã£o foi inicialmente divulgada pelo portal Uol. Os jornalistas afastados, que incluem Gian Oddi, Paulo CalÃ§ade, Pedro Ivo Almeida, Victor Birner, William Tavares e o produtor do programa, Dimas Coppede, devem retornar Ã s suas funÃ§Ãµes nesta quinta-feira (10).
A principal razÃ£o para o afastamento foi a falta de informaÃ§Ã£o antecipada sobre o conteÃºdo do programa, o que gerou desconforto entre os executivos da ESPN. Em consequÃªncia disso, a direÃ§Ã£o decidiu alterar a formaÃ§Ã£o do Linha de Passe exibido na terÃ§a-feira, 8 de abril. Assim, o programa contou com a presenÃ§a de AndrÃ© Pilhal, AndrÃ© Kfouri, Breiler Pires, EugÃªnio Leal e Leonardo Bertozzi.
CBF nega interferÃªncia A CBF se manifestou e negou envolver-se na decisÃ£o da ESPN. Em nota, a entidade esclareceu que nÃ£o pressionou a emissora para que tomasse tal medida. AlÃ©m disso, a ConfederaÃ§Ã£o reiterou seu respeito pela liberdade de imprensa e destacou que nÃ£o interfere na linha editorial dos veÃ­culos de comunicaÃ§Ã£o.
â€œNÃ£o procede. A CBF respeita a liberdade de imprensa com responsabilidade e nÃ£o pede interferÃªncias de nenhum tipo na linha editorial de veÃ­culos de comunicaÃ§Ã£o. Qualquer narrativa diferente desta Ã© mentirosa e levianaâ€, afirmou a entidade.
Jornalista se posiciona O jornalista Gian Oddi tambÃ©m se pronunciou sobre o ocorrido. Em suas redes sociais, ele afirmou que seu retorno ao programa, previsto para quinta-feira, 10 de abril, sÃ³ aconteceria porque ele tinha a certeza de que continuaria a ter liberdade para expressar suas opiniÃµes, como sempre fez. Dessa forma, Oddi destacou que essa liberdade Ã© fundamental para seu trabalho.
â€œFala, pessoal. Estou gravando para falar sobre a matÃ©ria que saiu hoje no UOL e foi replicada em vÃ¡rios outros lugares, a respeito do Linha de Passe da Ãºltima segunda-feira, 7 de abril. Eu e meus colegas voltamos ao programa na quinta-feira. Sinceramente, se eu vou voltar Ã© porque sei que continuaremos a falar do jeito que sempre falamos, com a liberdade que sempre tive nesses mais de 15 anos contratados pelo Trajano. Essa liberdade Ã© fundamental para o nosso trabalho. Se isso nÃ£o fosse possÃ­vel, eu nÃ£o voltaria. Nem a ESPN, talvez nem o jornalismo esportivo, faria sentido para mimâ€, disse Oddi.
Ele tambÃ©m comentou a razÃ£o do afastamento, explicando que a direÃ§Ã£o da ESPN alegou que um programa como o exibido exigia que a emissora estivesse preparada para as possÃ­veis consequÃªncias.
â€œCertos processos precisam ser seguidos, e alguns nÃ£o foram, essa Ã© a explicaÃ§Ã£o que recebemosâ€, completou o jornalista.

author: Isabel Kershner
title: Differences among hostagesâ€™ families complicate Netanyahuâ€™s calculus - The Boston Globe
text:
JERUSALEM â€” As Israel awaited a signal from Egyptian and Qatari mediators about whether Hamasâ€™s military leaders were prepared to advance talks on a possible cease-fire and hostage release, differences among the families of the more than 100 captives remaining in the Gaza Strip were emerging.
Some are pushing for a deal at all costs, while others are urging the government to fight on against Hamas until victory. For months, the families of the hostages have been a key â€” and largely united â€” voice in putting pressure on the Israeli government to prioritize efforts to secure their release. Now some are backing calls for a tougher stance toward Hamas, including blocking all aid to Gaza, even as the government is under international pressure to increase humanitarian assistance.
Advertisement
Those differences have added to political fighting in Israel, where Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu is facing threats from coalition partners and sparring with the opposition leader, who has offered him political cover for a hostage release.
Hamasâ€™s exiled political leader, Ismail Haniyeh, said this week that Hamas had received the outline of a deal, sketched out Sunday by US, Israeli, Egyptian, and Qatari officials at a high-level meeting in Paris. Officials have said the deal describes a phased process beginning with a pause in the fighting for several weeks, to allow for the return of a first group of about three dozen of the most vulnerable hostages, including women and any children left alive, as well as sick or wounded captives, in return for Palestinian prisoners. Further stages could extend the truce and include other categories of hostages, including soldiers.
Hamas leaders have demanded that any deal ultimately brings an end to the war in Gaza â€” a condition that Netanyahu has rejected. Netanyahu said he would not release â€œthousandsâ€ of Palestinian prisoners but has not publicly ruled out releasing prisoners of value to Hamas, including many convicted of deadly attacks against Israelis.
Advertisement
As some details of the framework have become public, Itamar Ben-Gvir, the leader of a far-right party that Netanyahu relies on to hold a majority in parliament, has publicly threatened to leave the coalition, warning that â€œan excessive deal equals dismantling the government.â€ Bezalel Smotrich, the far-right minister of finance, has declared that ending the war is not an option.
In public, at least, Netanyahu was taking a hard line that appeared to be aimed at reassuring far-right coalition partners. In a video statement released late Wednesday, Netanyahu emphasized that he would not accept a deal â€œat any priceâ€ and reiterated that Israel would not withdraw its forces from Gaza or release thousands of Palestinian prisoners.
â€œWe are constantly working to release our hostages and to achieve the other objectives of the war: Hamasâ€™s destruction and to ensure that Gaza is not a threat to Israel,â€ he said. â€œWe are working on all three of them together, and we will not concede any of them.â€
With Netanyahuâ€™s hold on power tenuous, the leader of the opposition, Yair Lapid, offered this week to provide him with a political â€œsafety netâ€ for a hostage deal, either by voting for it from the opposition or by temporarily joining his government.
But the gesture was received with little enthusiasm by Netanyahuâ€™s conservative Likud party. â€œYair Lapid is pushing for an immediate end to the war, without a total victory,â€ the party said in a statement Wednesday. â€œWe will not agree to that.â€
Advertisement
Lapid has not called to stop the war and leave the Hamas leadership in Gaza in power, according to a person close to the opposition leader, but he has been critical of Netanyahuâ€™s refusal to present a strategy for the day after the war in Gaza and a vision for the future of the enclave.
In an interview published in Thursdayâ€™s Maariv newspaper, Lapid said that Netanyahu was â€œno longer fitâ€ to serve as prime minister and called for an alternative government without him, or for elections.
The pressure on Netanyahu has been rising as some relatives of captives in Gaza, alongside far-right politicians, have participated in protests at border crossings to try to block humanitarian assistance from entering the enclave.
Many relatives of hostages and their supporters have called for releasing hostages to be a higher priority than any other war goal, though others have urged the government not to agree to any cease-fire or â€œa skewed deal.â€
Some Israeli military reservists and relatives of hostages have planned a multiday march beginning Sunday near the Gaza border and culminating in a demonstration four days later in Jerusalem. â€œWe expect this war to continue until final victory,â€ organizers said in a statement.
More than 240 people were taken hostage during the Hamas-led terrorist attacks in southern Israel on Oct. 7, in which Israeli officials say 1,200 people were killed. During a seven-day pause in November, women and children were among more than 100 hostages released in exchange for Palestinian prisoners and detainees.
Advertisement

author: RFI
title: "Unos 45" migrantes han muerto en selva panameÃ±a este aÃ±o
text:
"Unos 45" migrantes han muerto en selva panameÃ±a este aÃ±o
Ciudad de PanamÃ¡ (AFP) â€“ "Unos 45" migrantes han muerto este aÃ±o mientras cruzaban la selva del DariÃ©n en su marcha hacia Estados Unidos, dijo este jueves el ministro de Seguridad de PanamÃ¡, Frank Ãbrego.
Primera modificaciÃ³n:
"Este aÃ±o, segÃºn reportes recibidos, unas 45 personas han perdido la vida al tratar de cruzar el territorio panameÃ±o", dijo Ãbrego, citado en un comunicado de su ministerio.
La selva del DariÃ©n, en la frontera entre Colombia y PanamÃ¡, se ha convertido en un corredor para los migrantes que desde SudamÃ©rica tratan de llegar a Estados Unidos, pese a que deben enfrentar grandes peligros como rÃ­os caudalosos, grupos criminales y animales salvajes.
"Las personas que llegan aquÃ­ vienen guiadas por coyotes, por habitantes nuestros, pero que al enfrentarte a esto sin ninguna preparaciÃ³n fÃ­sica, pueden sufrir un golpe de calor, baja de la moral y posteriormente se echan a morir", afirmÃ³ Ãbrego.
En anteriores ocasiones las autoridades panameÃ±as han dicho que era muy difÃ­cil conocer con exactitud el nÃºmero de personas que mueren en la jungla por lo inaccesible del terreno y la dificultad para encontrar los cadÃ¡veres, que en ocasiones son devorados por animales.
Este aÃ±o han hecho la peligrosa travesÃ­a por el DariÃ©n mÃ¡s de 231.000 personas, entre ellos 153.577 venezolanos, 14.598 ecuatorianos, 14.674 colombianos y 12.065 chinos, segÃºn cifras oficiales panameÃ±as.
En 2023, mÃ¡s de 520.000 personas cruzaron esa jungla, de los cuales dos tercios fueron venezolanos.
Para tratar de disuadir a los migrantes, PanamÃ¡ y Estados Unidos firmaron un acuerdo mediante el cual Washington se comprometiÃ³ a financiar con seis millones de dÃ³lares la deportaciÃ³n desde PanamÃ¡ de migrantes que crucen el DariÃ©n.
Este martes PanamÃ¡ deportÃ³, con asistencia de Estados Unidos, en un vuelo chÃ¡rter a 29 colombianos con antecedentes criminales que entraron al paÃ­s por la frontera selvÃ¡tica.
Este jueves el presidente panameÃ±o, JosÃ© RaÃºl Mulino, anunciÃ³ que en los prÃ³ximos dÃ­as deportarÃ¡ a migrantes ecuatorianos que entraron por el DariÃ©n.
"Progresivamente, iremos haciendo lo que corresponde [para contener el paso de migrantes por la selva], pero me anima ver que arrancamos el acuerdo con Estados Unidos", indicÃ³ Mulino.
Â© 2024 AFP

author: Abhijay Singh Rawat
title: Google Classroom Has Some New Tools to Help Teachers Track Student Progress
text:
Google Classroom launched new analytics and student-engagement features for schools subscribing to Education Plus. Educators can now access an Analytics tab on any class page and view targeted alerts on student progress. These include notices like â€œ3 studentsâ€™ grades rose by over 25% since last monthâ€ or warnings when multiple assignments are late.
On the Classwork page, teachers will spot a count showing how many students havenâ€™t opened attached Drive files. This tackles a common challenge: determining whether no submissions mean struggle or forgetfulness. With this signal, teachers can follow up individually or send class-wide reminders .
Admin rollouts follow a phased schedule. Student engagement metrics are active now. The Analytics tab appears on class pages by June?30, and the full set of alerts will reach all Education Plus domains by August?1 . However, access requires a Google Workspace for Education Plus license. Super admins automatically see analytics; they must grant access to other education leaders or staff .
Other recent Google news â€“
The updates build on Classroomâ€™s centralized dashboard, introduced in 2023. Instructors can now act faster. For example, if a student scores below 70% or a deadline looms and no one has begun an assignment, the system flags it. Teachers can intervene early. Insights appear based on performance issues or assignment timing .
Super admins and designated staff can temporarily access any class to view analytics or support teachers. This helps during substitute teaching or intervention .
These tools aim to reduce guesswork. Rather than relying on end-of-week grading, teachers can spot disengagement, unopened files, late submissions, and declining performance in real time. The rapid-release and scheduled-release rollout ensures districts see these features gradually. The Analytics tab reaches users by June?30, with full insights available by August?1.
By tightly integrating engagement tracking and alerts into Classroom, Google gives educators tools to respond quickly. This could improve outcomes and reduce last-minute catchups. The enhancements roll out over the summer to Google Workspace for Education Plus domains.
You may also be interested to read â€“
